thread.title: H.S. girls soccer: Holy Angels gets that elusive win - Girls Soccer
thread.title_full: H.S. girls soccer: Holy Angels gets that elusive win - Girls Soccer - NorthJersey.com

author: JJ CONRAD
title: H.S. girls soccer: Holy Angels gets that elusive win - Girls Soccer
text:
DEMAREST — Holy Angels coach Megan Delasandro has been wanting — and telling — senior captain Alexa Vecchione to start shooting more.
Sunday, we saw why.
Locked in a scoreless tie against Glen Rock in the opening round of the Bergen County girls soccer tournament, Vecchione ripped a high-arcing, rainbow shot from 35 yards that found the back of the net in the 45th minute.
For players who have "doubted themselves in the past," Delasandro said, Vecchione’s highlight-reel goal propelled the 16th-seeded Angels to a 2-0 win over 17th-seeded Glen Rock for their first BCT victory in "a long time." 
"I think we wanted to prove to everybody how good of a program we are," said Delasandro, whose team — which competes in the competitive Big North United — improved to 5-5.
"We wanted to show everyone that we deserve some recognition."
With Glen Rock creating more scoring opportunities in the first half and early in the second, Vecchione’s deep blast swung momentum heavily into the Angels’ favor.
An animated fist pump from Vecchione followed near midfield before the talented midfielder was mobbed by her jubilant teammates.
"She has one of the most powerful shots from outside the 18," Delasandro said. "We’ve seen goals like that from her in the past, but sometimes she doesn’t trust her own range, even though she’s proven she can do it.
"She’s been in a bit of a mental slump. She’s putting pressure on her own shoulders to show everyone that she can lead this team. But she’s an all-in kid who absolutely wears her heart on her sleeve. She plays with a lot of passion."
The go-ahead goal gave the Angels the confidence they needed. Junior goalie Kerry Sammon — athletic, smart and vocal in net — continued to shine on the county stage and finished with 11 saves. 
Junior sweeper Gabrielle Guillou, making her Angels debut after transferring from NV/Old Tappan, was a defensive force on the back line and showcased a booming leg on restarts.
Senior Nicole Yi provided an insurance goal — assisted by Holly Slepian — after knocking home a loose ball in front of the net with 10:02 left.
Though they were home and seeded higher than Glen Rock, it’s been the perennially strong Panthers featured in The Record Top 25 poll all season.
Holy Angels has been on the outside looking in, but that could change.
"We needed a win like this," Delasandro said.
"We’re a team that’s never ranked. But we’re a strong group that keeps pushing forward. We were determined to prove that we were ready to take the next step."
The next step will be the most challenging. A date with top-seeded and undefeated Northern Highlands awaits in the round of 16.
The Angels know the odds are stacked against them, but they remain excited about the opportunity to measure themselves against the consensus top-ranked team in the nation.
"It will be fun because we’ve never played them in recent years," Delasandro said. "Sometimes girls will go in with preconceived notions about what to expect. But you won’t ever know until you play them.
"If anything, we want to go out and prove how talented we are. If we walk away with a win, that’s amazing. But it’s more about going out there and seeing if we can hang. The girls have worked hard. We want to keep showing it."
